channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the French Election Results Unfolded
item.description: A left-wing coalition unexpectedly surged and the far-right National Rally fell short of predictions. But no coalition captured a majority in Parliament, meaning months of gridlock could lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: In Rafah, We Saw Destruction and the Limits of Israel’s Gaza Strategy
item.description: Months after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared that “victory is within reach,” the Israeli military escorted journalists into parts of a devastated Gazan city.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Adam Goldman/The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged and destroyed buildings in the Tal al-Sultan neighborhood of Rafah, a city in the southern Gaza Strip, as seen while on an embed with the Israeli military.

item.title: Israelis Call for a Cease-Fire Deal and Elections After 9 Months of War
item.description: A day of nationwide anti-government protests comes amid signs of progress toward a truce and hostage deal with Hamas, as well as continued fighting.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Illean/Associated Press
item.media:description: The police dispersing demonstrators blocking a road in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Turnout Is High as France’s Snap Election Enters Its Final Hours
item.description: The vote will determine the composition of France’s National Assembly, and the future of President Emmanuel Macron’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters casting their ballots in Paris on Sunday during the second round of voting in France’s snap election.

item.title: Deadly Flooding and Landslides in Nepal
item.description: In this monsoon season, so far there have been more than 60 weather-related fatalities. With roads cut off and more rain expected, the toll could rise.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Niranjan Shrestha/Associated Press
item.media:description: The flooded Bagmati River in Nepal’s capital, Kathmandu, on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Stay Neutral in Political Dogfight Between Trump and Biden
item.description: With President Biden’s future unclear, Donald J. Trump’s support uncertain and a major NATO meeting looming, Ukrainian leaders are straining to keep their balance.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Biden at the Group of 7 summit in Savelletri, Italy, last month.

item.title: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike Is Re-elected in Race With 56 Candidates
item.description: A ridiculous number of candidates contended to be governor of Tokyo and its surrounding prefecture. Many were not even trying to win.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An election poster board displaying candidates in the election for governor of Tokyo.

item.title: The Windmills Are Back Up on the Moulin Rouge
item.description: The Paris landmark has completed its restoration after the blades fell off this spring — and just in time for the Summer Olympic Games to begin.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Christophe Petit Tesson/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Moulin Rouge hosted an outdoor performance on Friday to celebrate the restoration of its iconic windmill.

item.title: Masoud Pezeshkian, Iran’s New President, Raises Hope for a Diplomatic Opening
item.description: Masoud Pezeshkian, a reformist, wants warmer relations with the West, with the goal of ending sanctions. But his powers are strictly limited.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud Pezeshkian, center, casting his vote in the second round of presidential elections in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The left surges in French elections.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the results in Place de la République in Paris.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From France’s Snap Election
item.description: It was a day of big surprises in France, with the left surging unexpectedly, the far right falling far short of expectations and the question of who will be the next prime minister still unclear.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Place de la République in Paris on Sunday after the results of the French election came in.

item.title: Soaring Temperatures and Profit Seekers Amplify Dangers on the Hajj
item.description: “The halls felt like they were on fire,” one Jordanian woman said of her accommodations after she opted to take a cheaper travel package for “unregistered” pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Rana F. Sweis, Emad Mekay and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Muslims performing the Eid al-Adha morning prayer around the Kaaba, Islam’s holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on June 16, marking the end of the hajj pilgrimage.

item.title: Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Leader, Meets With Xi in China After Talks With Putin
item.description: Mr. Orban said his visit to Beijing was part of a “peace mission” for Ukraine. But both leaders want to offset Western power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: X account of Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Viktor Orban, the Hungarian prime minister, left, meeting with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, in Beijing on Monday,

item.title: How the Far-Right National Rally Did in France’s Elections
item.description: The party fell short of expectations but had captured its highest number of National Assembly seats.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jordan Bardella, the president of the National Rally, said his party’s centrist and left-wing rivals had “deprived” France of a far-right government through their political strategy.

item.title: France’s New Popular Front Was Formed to Keep Far Right From Power
item.description: The left-wing alliance includes the divisive Jean-Luc Mélenchon, a combative politician who has been accused of antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Monday Briefing: Left Surges in French Election
item.description: Plus, a reformist will be Iran’s next president.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Philippe Lopez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bicycle rally for the New Popular Front in Bordeaux, France.

item.title: France’s Campaign Season Was Marred by Racist Attacks and Violent Acts
item.description: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said that more than 50 people — including candidates, their substitutes or supporters — had been “physically assaulted” during the campaign.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Teresa Suarez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prisca Thevenot, the government spokeswoman, is one of more than 50 people who have been the target of racist attacks during the campaign.

item.title: French Election Yields Deadlock as Left Surges and Far Right Comes Up Short
item.description: The outcome left no party with an absolute majority and France bracing for potential political paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the left-wing alliance celebrating the results of the French election in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: France Could Be Headed for Political Gridlock After Election
item.description: Experts said the country could be headed for months of political instability, with the National Assembly divided into three major blocs that appear unable to work with the others.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking nearby a polling station in the surroundings of the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: Here Are the Key Players in France’s 2024 Election
item.description: The vote has turned into a race between the two main opponents of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party: the far-right National Rally and the New Popular Front, a left-wing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: New Plan to Target Russia’s Oil Revenue Brings Debate in White House
item.description: Treasury officials want to impose penalties on tankers that help Russian oil evade sanctions. White House aides worry that risks making gasoline more expensive.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Tatiana Meel/Reuters
item.media:description: The development of Russia’s shadow fleet of tankers and alternative forms of maritime insurance have allowed the Kremlin to continue generating robust revenues from oil exports, helping it to finance its war against Ukraine.

item.title: Farage and the Future of the U.K.’s Conservative Party
item.description: In the shadow of Labour’s landslide victory over the upended Conservatives, Nigel Farage’s small insurgent right-wing party, Reform U.K., is on a roll.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Oli Scarff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of the right-wing insurgent party Reform U.K., reacted to hecklers at an election victory speech on Friday. He won a Parliament seat for the first time in eight attempts.

item.title: Pakistan Withers Under Deadly Heat and Fears the Coming Rains
item.description: Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city, endured days of temperatures above 100 Fahrenheit, made worse by power cuts and high humidity.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Insiya Syed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doctors examining young children suffering from fevers and heat exhaustion at a government hospital in Karachi, Pakistan, on Friday.

item.title: 4 Takeaways From Iran’s Presidential Runoff
item.description: The victory of the reformist candidate, Masoud Pezeshkian, is expected to bring change, but to what extent is still an open question.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The winner of Iran’s presidential runoff, reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian, on the last day of campaigning in Tehran last week.

item.title: Hamas’s Cease-Fire Proposal Includes a Familiar Sticking Point
item.description: Hamas wants assurances that Israel won’t restart the war after some hostages come home. Israel says it needs the option.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Jehad Alshrafi/Associated Press
item.media:description: The streets of Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Wayne S. Smith, a Leading Critic of the Embargo on Cuba, Dies at 91
item.description: A former State Department official, he resigned in protest in 1982 over Cuba policy, then spent decades trying to rebuild relations with the island nation.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Alan Diaz/Associated Press
item.media:description: Wayne Smith spoke to a group of Cuban Americans in Miami in 2005. “He was one of the foremost spokespeople in favor of normalizing relations,” a Cuba expert said.

item.title: Mythical Sword’s Disappearance Brings Mystery to French Village
item.description: Legend says the Durandal sword had been stuck in a French hillside for nearly 1,300 years. When it went missing in June, an investigation to find France’s Excalibur began.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders and William Lamb
item.media:credit: Grantibo/Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Durandal sword, which has gone missing from the rock in which it had been stuck for nearly 1,300 years, in Rocamadour, southern France, in 2017.

item.title: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer Is About to Get a Crash Course in Statecraft
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer will travel to a NATO summit this coming week, where he will represent a rare point of centrist stability among unsettled allies.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Keir Starmer, outside 10 Downing Street in London on Friday, after his Labour Party’s landslide election victory.

item.title: Facing New ‘Greenwashing’ Law, an Oil Industry Website Goes Dark
item.description: Oil sands companies pushing a carbon capture project shut down their website after a law banning misleading environmental claims was passed.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pathways Alliance is seeking billions of dollars in subsidies to capture oil sands carbon emissions.

item.title: Developing Your Taste
item.description: The meals that we love are informed as much by the experience of eating them as by the flavor of the food itself.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: In the French Countryside, the Far-Right National Rally Has Risen
item.description: In northern Burgundy, services have collapsed and the far-right National Rally has risen.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters for Sophie-Laurence Roy, left, a National Rally candidate, and her centrist runoff opponent, André Villiers, in Nitry, France.

item.title: What Do Bagged Chickens Have to Do With Sliced Cheese?
item.description: Both have gotten caught up in fights over plastic packaging. When Costco recently tried to trim its plastic use by selling rotisserie chickens in bags, some shoppers disapproved.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Smith Collection/Gado, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Costco switched to thin bags from heavier clamshells, annoying some chicken lovers.

item.title: Abductions Rattle Kenya as Anti-Government Protests Continue
item.description: Dozens of activists say they were snatched from their homes or off the streets by hooded, armed men. Some are still missing, and the disappearances have unnerved a nation long seen as a pillar of stability.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters threw stones at police during an anti-government demonstration in Nairobi on Tuesday.

item.title: Violence, Rape, Thirst, Even Organ Theft: Migrants Face Lethal Risks in Africa
item.description: The danger to migrants while crossing the Mediterranean is well documented, but an earlier phase of their trek, across the Sahel and the Sahara, is deadlier, researchers say in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men loading supplies into a pickup in Agadez, Niger, last year. Thousands of people travel each week from Agadez toward North Africa, where many will then try to cross the Mediterranean.

item.title: Can Foreigners Handle the Heat? Mexico City Debates Milder Salsas.
item.description: As more foreigners, especially Americans, visit or move to Mexico City, some taco shops have lowered the heat in their sauces. Not everyone is happy.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.media:description: Mexico City’s tacos are beloved by locals and visitors alike.

item.title: In Ukraine, Killings of Unarmed Russians Divide a U.S.-Led Unit
item.description: A German medic said he was so troubled that he confronted his commander. Others boasted about killings in a group chat.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: via Caspar Grosse
item.media:description: Caspar Grosse, a medic in an international volunteer unit in Ukraine, said he wrote this journal entry in October after a fellow soldier, known as Zeus, recounted executing a Russian prisoner.

item.title: Masoud Pezeshkian Wins Iran’s Presidential Election
item.description: Masoud Pezeshkian, a cardiac surgeon and relative moderate in the ruling establishment, defeated an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator in a runoff.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud Pezeshkian waving to supporters at a campaign rally in Tehran on the last day of campaigning on Wednesday.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Allowed to Leave Romania in Latest Court Decision
item.description: The court in Bucharest ruled that Mr. Tate and his brother, who are facing human trafficking and rape charges, must remain in the European Union as they await trial, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Robert Ghement/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, a social media influencer, said he was “free” to leave Romania in a video posted on social media on Friday. His lawyer confirmed that a court in Bucharest ruled that he could travel within the European Union while awaiting trial.

item.title: New Popular Front Scored Big in France’s Vote. Who Are Its Members?
item.description: Parties on the left were so fractious, they broke up their alliance months ago, but the possibility of a government controlled by the far right drew them back together.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Olivier Faure, left, and other left-wing coalition members waving during an open-air legislative election campaign meeting in the Paris suburbs in June.

item.title: Labour Won a U.K. Landslide. Why Doesn’t It Feel Like That?
item.description: Keir Starmer’s party won a huge majority in parliament. But the new prime minister faces a fractious and volatile public.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new Prime Minister, Keir Starmer, speaking outside 10 Downing Street on Friday.

item.title: Reform U.K.’s Success Is Latest Sign of Strength for Europe’s Far Right
item.description: The insurgent anti-immigration party led by Nigel Farage secured around 14 percent of the vote in Britain’s general election, though it has won only five parliamentary seats.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nigel Farage celebrating in Clacton-on-Sea, England, early Friday.

item.title: Count Binface and Elmo Provided a Bit of Comic Relief in Britain’s Elections
item.description: As has long been the tradition in Britain, the elections included various joke candidates who often run against prominent politicians.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elmo kept smiling through his election loss on Thursday night.

item.title: Who Is Angela Rayner, Britain’s Deputy Prime Minister?
item.description: While politics in Britain have traditionally been dominated by the country’s elites, Ms. Rayner has taken a less traditional route to the top.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Angela Rayner arriving at 10 Downing Street on Friday.

item.title: Vatican Excommunicates Its Former Ambassador to the U.S.
item.description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, who was informed of his excommunication on Friday, has long been a vocal critic of Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alex Washburn/Associated Press
item.media:description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò speaking at a “Walk for Life” rally by abortion opponents in San Francisco in 2015.

item.title: Who Is David Lammy, Britain’s New Foreign Secretary?
item.description: Mr. Lammy has deep ties to the United States and campaigned for former President Barack Obama.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Lammy in the North London town of Tottenham in April.

item.title: Kazakh Journalist’s Killing Sends Chill Through Exiles in Ukraine
item.description: Aidos Sadykov, an opposition activist whose YouTube channel often criticizes Kazakhstan’s government, was shot in Ukraine, where he was living in exile.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the body of Aidos Sadykov, an opposition activist and journalist from Kazakhstan, to be buried on Friday.

item.title: Labour Wins Back the Trust of Jewish Voters
item.description: Keir Starmer had made rooting out antisemitism from the Labour Party’s ranks a goal of his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, who describes himself as an atheist, is married to Victoria Starmer, who comes from a Jewish family.

item.title: Who Is Rachel Reeves, the Woman Taking the Helm of the U.K.’s Economy?
item.description: As the newly named chancellor of the Exchequer, she is taking on the tough job of boosting Britain’s productivity growth and of reviving struggling public services.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, the new chancellor of the Exchequer, right, with Keir Starmer, the new prime minister, last month.

item.title: Brazil Police Accuse Bolsonaro of Embezzling Saudi Jewels
item.description: Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, may soon face criminal charges for stealing gifts he received from foreign leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former Brazilian president, at a political rally in February in São Paulo.

item.title: Five Takeaways From the U.K. General Election
item.description: The Labour Party won a resounding victory over the Conservatives, but smaller parties, including the populist Reform, did better than expected.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reacting to election results at a watch party in a London pub on Thursday.

item.title: Sometimes It Is the Coach’s Fault
item.description: The U.S. collapsed under the weight of expectations at the Copa América. Its next move could determine if there is a repeat, or a revival, at the 2026 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.media:credit: Erik S Lesser/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The United States tumbled out of the Copa América and right into a self-inflicted crisis.

item.title: The Greens Take a Bite of Labour’s Vote Share
item.description: The left-leaning Green Party, which is particularly popular with people under 30, took seven percent of the vote and will now have four lawmakers in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Green Party co-leaders Carla Denyer, left, and Adrian Ramsay, at their election manifesto launch in Hove, England, in June.

item.title: Keir Starmer Vows ‘National Renewal’ in First Speech as UK Prime Minister
item.description: The Labour leader promised in a speech in Downing Street to restore Britain’s faith in politics and public service.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. Liberal Democrats Make Big Election Gains
item.description: The small centrist party campaigned on improving health and social care. Its leader, Ed Davey, wooed voters with publicity stunts and personal appeals.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ed Davey, leader of the Liberal Democrat party, speaking in Whittlesford, England, in May.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Revive After Weeks of Deadlock
item.description: The negotiations had been stalled for weeks until Hamas announced on Wednesday that it had exchanged some ideas with mediators on a new way forward.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: An Israeli tank near the border with Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Britain’s New Prime Minister Had Just Hours to Prepare
item.description: A new U.S. president usually has a two-month window to prepare to move into the White House. Freshly elected British prime ministers move into Downing Street much more swiftly.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The famed address has been home to prime ministers since 1735. And it’s much larger than it seems from the street.
